page.title: 06Lea Hall - Hatfield Heath
page.content: Lea Hall is one of several listed buildings in the area and it was built in 1590. It was named after a man called John de la Lea which means John of the Lea. The grounds extend for 12 acres and the house is surrounded by a moat which is as much as 12 feet deep in places. During World War II, Italian prisoners from a nearby camp cleaned it out. When the present owners moved into Lea Hall, five years ago the bridges going over the moat were old and unsafe so they had to be replaced and new ones built. An archway into Lea Hall has been brought from Hull and also an old church window frame has been brought from Yorkshire and placed in the grounds. A small group of children from our school visited Lea Hall and spent an enjoyable afternoon there.
